The Earth's orbit and tilt determine the changes in day length during the year. As the Earth orbits the sun, one hemisphere moves towards the sun while the other moves away, resulting in changes in the length of day and night. The Northern Hemisphere tilts away from the sun during winter, causing shorter days. This tilt affects the amount of sunlight the hemisphere receives and the length of the day.

On the other hand, the Earth's closest approach to the sun (perihelion) occurs around January 3rd, so moving closer to the sun during winter would result in longer days, not shorter ones.

I will use a common causal model to help determine the likely cause of this relationship. The independent variable (IV) here is the decrease in charity donations, and the dependent variable (DV) is the decrease in pet adoptions.

According to Granger causality, if knowing the recent history of one variable helps predict the future of another variable, then the first variable is said to Granger cause the second variable. If knowing the present value of one variable doesn't help predict the present value of the other variable, but knowing the past values of both variables helps, then both variables may be caused by each other or a common factor (confounder).

In this case, a decrease in charity donations could make it harder for animal welfare organizations to take care of animals and offer them for adoption.
